Vertical Federated Learning without Revealing Intersection Membership

Jiankai Sun
jiankai.sun@bytedance.com &Xin Yang11footnotemark: 1
yangxin.yx@bytedance.com Yuanshun Yao
kevin.yao@bytedance.com

chong.wang@bytedance.com Equal contribution. Correspondence to: {jiankai.sun, yangxin.yx, chong.wang}@bytedance.com
Abstract

Vertical Federated Learning (vFL) allows multiple parties that own different attributes (e.g. features and labels) of the same data entity (e.g. a person) to jointly train a model. To prepare the training data, vFL needs to identify the common data entities shared by all parties. It is usually achieved by Private Set Intersection (PSI) which identifies the intersection of training samples from all parties by using personal identifiable information (e.g. email) as sample IDs to align data instances. As a result, PSI would make sample IDs of the intersection visible to all parties, and therefore each party can know that the data entities shown in the intersection also appear in the other parties, i.e. intersection membership. However, in many real-world privacy-sensitive organizations, e.g. banks and hospitals, revealing membership of their data entities is prohibited. In this paper, we propose a vFL framework based on Private Set Union (PSU) that allows each party to keep sensitive membership information to itself. Instead of identifying the intersection of all training samples, our PSU protocol generates the union of samples as training instances. In addition, we propose strategies to generate synthetic features and labels to handle samples that belong to the union but not the intersection. Through extensive experiments on two real-world datasets, we show our framework can protect the privacy of the intersection membership while maintaining the model utility.

1 Introduction

With the increasing tension between data privacy and data-hungry machine learning, Federated Learning (FL) (McMahan et al., 2017; Hanzely et al., 2020; Yuan and Ma, 2020; Ghosh et al., 2020) is proposed as a privacy-enhancing technique that allows multiple parties to collaboratively train a model without completely sharing data. Depending on how data are split across parties, FL can be mainly classified into two categories (Yang et al., 2019a): Horizontal Federated Learning (Geiping et al., 2020; Hamer et al., 2020; Karimireddy et al., 2020; Li et al., 2020) and Vertical Federated Learning (Vepakomma et al., 2018; Gupta and Raskar, 2018; Abuadbba et al., 2020; Ceballos et al., 2020). In Horizontal FL, data is split by entity (e.g. a person), and data entities owned by each party are complete and disjoint from other parties. In Vertical FL (vFL), a data entity is split into different attributes (e.g. features and labels of the same person), and each party might own the same data entity but different attributes. One typical example of vFL is a collaboration between general and specialized hospitals. They might hold the data for the same patient, but the general hospital owns generic information (i.e. features) of the patient while the specialized hospital owns the specific testing results (i.e. labels) of the same patient. Therefore they can use vFL to jointly train a model that predicts a specific disease examined by the specialized hospital from the features provided by the general hospital.

One critical stage in vFL is identifying the same entities shared by all parties which we define as intersection. In standard vFL, this is achieved by Private Set Intersection (PSI) protocols  (Kolesnikov et al., 2016; Pinkas et al., 2018). Before the training starts, all parties need to run PSI protocols to identify the intersection to align sample IDs. The sample ID needs to be certain universally identifiable information that can be used to identify entities across organizations. The common option is some personal identifiable information (e.g. phone and email). After all parties obtain the sample IDs of the intersection, they can jointly train a model on the intersection.

However, the PSI protocol would make the sample IDs of the intersection visible to all parties. As a result, every party would know that the entities in the intersection also exist in the other parties’ data, and we define this information as intersection membership. In many real-world privacy-sensitive organizations, membership information is highly sensitive and cannot be shared with the other parties. For example, hospitals cannot reveal which patient is a member and banks cannot disclose which client owns an account. In practice, this leakage significantly limits the applicability of vFL since vFL participants are privacy-sensitive but the membership leakage conflicts with the privacy-preserving intention of using vFL.

Only a few of existing work attempts to address the intersection membership leakage problem in vFL. Existing work in protecting the privacy of vFL mostly focuses on preventing data leakage (Chen et al., 2020; Wu et al., 2020; Li et al., 2021) rather than membership leakage. The closest work is (Liu et al., 2020), which adapts PSI to achieve the asymmetrical ID alignment in an asymmetrical vFL. However, their protocol still exposes the intersection membership to one party and cannot protect all parties. To the best of our knowledge, our work is the first attempt to protect intersection membership information for all parties.

In this paper, we design a novel vFL framework to address the problem of intersection membership leakage. Our framework can train models without revealing the membership information while maintaining the model utility. To achieve our goal, we need to overcome two main technical challenges: 1) How to securely align training samples without the knowledge of their intersection? 2) How to design an effective learning mechanism based on the secured alignments to protect privacy while retaining the model utility?

To answer the questions, we propose a novel Private Set Union (PSU) protocol that does not reveal sample IDs of the intersection, and therefore no membership information about the intersection would be leaked. Instead, it identifies the union of the training instances and uses it as the training data in our framework. In addition, we design several strategies to generate synthetic features and labels for samples that belong to the union but not the intersection. We summarize our contributions as follows:

  • •

    We propose the first vFL framework that protects the membership information of all parties.

  • •

    We design a novel Private Set Union protocol that can securely align data entities without revealing membership information of the intersection.

  • •

    We design several synthetic data generation strategies for samples which belong to the union but not the intersection. Through extensive experiments, we show our strategies are both secure and utility-preserving.

2 Methodology

2.1 Background: Vertical Federated Learning

We formally describe the gradient-based two-party vFL settings. Let 𝒟=(ℐ,𝒳,𝒴)𝒟ℐ𝒳𝒴\mathcal{D}=(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{X},\mathcal{Y}) denote a complete dataset with ℐℐ\mathcal{I}, 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, and 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} representing the sample ID space, the feature space, and the label space, respectively. A two-party vFL is conducted over two datasets 𝒟p=(ℐp,𝒳p,𝒴p)subscript𝒟𝑝subscriptℐ𝑝subscript𝒳𝑝subscript𝒴𝑝\mathcal{D}_{p}=(\mathcal{I}_{p},\mathcal{X}_{p},\mathcal{Y}_{p}), 𝒟a=(ℐa,𝒳a,𝒴a)subscript𝒟𝑎subscriptℐ𝑎subscript𝒳𝑎subscript𝒴𝑎\mathcal{D}_{a}=(\mathcal{I}_{a},\mathcal{X}_{a},\mathcal{Y}_{a}), satisfying 𝒳p≠𝒳a,𝒴p=∅,𝒴p≠𝒴a,ℐp∩ℐa≠∅formulae-sequencesubscript𝒳𝑝subscript𝒳𝑎formulae-sequencesubscript𝒴𝑝formulae-sequencesubscript𝒴𝑝subscript𝒴𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝subscriptℐ𝑎\mathcal{X}_{p}\neq\mathcal{X}_{a},\mathcal{Y}_{p}=\emptyset,\mathcal{Y}_{p}\neq\mathcal{Y}_{a},\mathcal{I}_{p}\cap\mathcal{I}_{a}\neq\emptyset. We refer the party 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} without labels (𝒴p=∅subscript𝒴𝑝\mathcal{Y}_{p}=\emptyset) as the passive party and the party 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} with labels as the active party.

Here we focus on two parties learning a model for a binary classification problem over the domain 𝒳×{0,1}𝒳01\mathcal{X}\times\left\{0,1\right\}. The passive and active parties want to learn a composition model h∘fℎ𝑓h\circ f jointly, where the raw features X𝑋X and f:𝒳→ℝd:𝑓→𝒳superscriptℝ𝑑f:\mathcal{X}\to\operatorname{\mathbb{R}}^{d} are stored on the passive party side while the labels y𝑦y and h:ℝd→ℝ:ℎ→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝh:\operatorname{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\to\operatorname{\mathbb{R}} is on the active party side. Let ℓ=h​(f​(X))ℓℎ𝑓𝑋\ell=h(f(X)) be the logit111In our case, we add no additional features in the active party to compute the logit and set 𝒳a=∅subscript𝒳𝑎\mathcal{X}_{a}=\emptyset. of the positive class where the positive class’s predicted probability is given by the sigmoid function. The loss L𝐿L of the model is given by the cross entropy. The passive party sends the computation result, f​(𝒳p)𝑓subscript𝒳𝑝f(\mathcal{X}_{p}) of the intermediate layer (called the cut layer) rather than the raw data 𝒳psubscript𝒳𝑝\mathcal{X}_{p} to the active party. The active party computes the gradient of L𝐿L with respect to the input of the function hℎh. We denote this gradient by g𝑔g (equality by chain rule). After receiving g𝑔g sent from the active party, the passive party computes the gradient of L𝐿L w.r.t. f𝑓f’s parameters. It is straightforward to apply stochastic gradient descent (SGD) to this setting.

As discussed in Section 1, before we run the training algorithm, we need to prepare data by first aligning the training data using PSI (Pinkas et al., 2018; Kolesnikov et al., 2016). However this will inevitably leak intersection membership.

2.2 Overview of FLORIST

We propose Federated Learning withOut Revealing InterSecTions, or FLORIST, to remove the need of revealing the intersection membership in vFL. Specifically, we perform mini-batch SGD training on the union of the training samples. As shown in Figure 1, our framework consists of two modules: Private Set Union (PSU) for ID alignment and synthetic data generation. PSU is designed to align data samples securely without exposing sample IDs of the intersection.PSU outputs a set of universal IDs with which both parties schedule the mini-batch training. First, in PSU, no information on the intersection set, except for the size of the intersection, is revealed. Second, when a party (either passive or active) is given a training sample (i​di,xi,yi)𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖({id}_{i},{x}_{i},{y}_{i}) in a mini-batch generated from the union, it is possible that i​di𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖id_{i} is not in its dataset. Therefore the party needs to generate synthetic data to ensure a valid training procedure. For example, as shown in Figure 1, the passive party provides synthetic features for [p4]delimited-[]subscript𝑝4[p_{4}], and the active party provides synthetic labels for [p2]delimited-[]subscript𝑝2[p_{2}] and [p3]delimited-[]subscript𝑝3[p_{3}], where [.][.] represents the encrypted ID space.

Threat Model.

We assume malicious parties are honest-but-curious, i.e. 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} and 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} faithfully run the vFL protocol, but they may infer important information including raw sample data and intersection membership from the exchanged information. In particular, we consider two privacy leakage scenarios: 1) for i​d∈ℐa𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑎id\in\mathcal{I}_{a}, 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} finds out if i​d∈ℐa∩ℐp𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝id\in\mathcal{I}_{a}\cap\mathcal{I}_{p} by checking yi​dsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑑y_{id} and the embedding forwarded by 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p}, and 2) for i​d∈ℐp𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑝id\in\mathcal{I}_{p}, 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} finds out if i​d∈ℐa∩ℐp𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝id\in\mathcal{I}_{a}\cap\mathcal{I}_{p} by checking xi​dsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑑x_{id} and the gradient sent back by 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a}.

2.3 Private Set Union for ID-alignment

We first introduce our PSU protocol for secured entity alignment. On a high level, by running the PSU protocol, parties 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} and 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} jointly compute a bijection u:(ℐa∪ℐp)↔U:𝑢subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝↔𝑈u:(\mathcal{I}_{a}\cup\mathcal{I}_{p})\leftrightarrow U, where U𝑈U is a set of encrypted universal identifiers (UID) shared by both parties. Furthermore, the active party 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} knows u​(i​d)𝑢𝑖𝑑u(id) for all i​d∈ℐa𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑎id\in\mathcal{I}_{a} and the passive party 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} knows u​(i​d)𝑢𝑖𝑑u(id) for all i​d∈ℐp𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑝id\in\mathcal{I}_{p}. Therefore the membership information that can be inferred from sample IDs aligned by PSI would not be leaked by PSU. Finally, under the decisional Diffie–Hellman assumption, our PSU protocol leaks no information other than |ℐa|,|ℐp|,|ℐa∩ℐp|subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝|\mathcal{I}_{a}|,|\mathcal{I}_{p}|,|\mathcal{I}_{a}\cap\mathcal{I}_{p}| to an honest-but-curious malicious party.

The set U𝑈U is used to schedule mini-batch training in the following way: for each batch, both parties agree on a sequence u1,u2,⋯∈Usubscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2⋯𝑈u_{1},u_{2},\cdots\in U. For each uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, both parties check whether u−1​(ui)superscript𝑢1subscript𝑢𝑖u^{-1}(u_{i}) is contained in their own ID set, and if so, they feed the corresponding real data into the model; otherwise, they apply the data generation methods (detailed described in Section 2.4) to generate synthetic data to feed into the model.

Our PSU protocol is presented in Algorithm 1. It consists of two parallel independent parts: in the first part, both parties jointly compute the union of UID, but they do not know the mapping from the ID set to U𝑈U. We use two rounds of Diffie–Hellman key exchange scheme so that 𝒫a,𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑎subscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{a},\mathcal{P}_{p} cannot identify if some sample ID is in the intersection. In the second part, 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} and 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} compute the mapping from ℐa,ℐpsubscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝\mathcal{I}_{a},\mathcal{I}_{p} to U𝑈U respectively.

We present the security guarantee of our PSU protocol. The security assumption is based on the hardness of the Decisional Diffie–Hellman (DDH) problem. Let p𝑝p be a prime satisfying that q=p−12𝑞𝑝12q=\frac{p-1}{2} is also a prime. (p𝑝p is a so-called safe prime). It is commonly believed that DDH is hard for Q​R​(ℤp∗)𝑄𝑅superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑝QR(\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{*}), where Q​R​(ℤp∗):={x|∃y,y2≡x(modp)}assign𝑄𝑅superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑝conditional-set𝑥𝑦superscript𝑦2annotated𝑥pmod𝑝QR(\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{*}):=\{x|\exists y,y^{2}\equiv x\pmod{p}\} is the quadratic residues of the cyclic group ℤp∗superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑝\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{*}. Here we assume that both ℐasubscriptℐ𝑎\mathcal{I}_{a} and ℐpsubscriptℐ𝑝\mathcal{I}_{p} have already been pre-processed so that they are encoded in Q​R​(ℤp∗)𝑄𝑅superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑝QR(\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{*}).

Our security argument is based on simulation, which is a standard proof technique for proving privacy against honest-but-curious adversary Lindell (2017). Here we present an informal statement and more detailed analysis can be found in Appendix A.

Theorem 1 (Security Guarantee of PSU).

Let n:=max⁡{|ℐa|,|ℐp|,⌈log⁡p⌉}assign𝑛subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝𝑝n:=\max\{|\mathcal{I}_{a}|,|\mathcal{I}_{p}|,\lceil\log p\rceil\} be the security parameter. Assume DDH is hard for Q​R​(ℤp∗)𝑄𝑅superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑝QR(\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{*}), then for malicious 𝒫∈{𝒫a,𝒫p}𝒫subscript𝒫𝑎subscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}\in\{\mathcal{P}_{a},\mathcal{P}_{p}\} that runs in time polynomial in n𝑛n, 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} learns nothing other than |ℐa|,|ℐp|,|ℐa∪ℐp|subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝|\mathcal{I}_{a}|,|\mathcal{I}_{p}|,|\mathcal{I}_{a}\cup\mathcal{I}_{p}| by running Algorithm 1.

2.4 Synthetic Data Generation

Given a training sample (i​di,xi,yi)𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖({id}_{i},{x}_{i},{y}_{i}) in a mini-batch generated from the union of all samples, it is possible that i​di𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖id_{i} is not in ℐasubscriptℐ𝑎\mathcal{I}_{a} or ℐpsubscriptℐ𝑝\mathcal{I}_{p}. In such cases, 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} or 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} need to generate synthetic data. We introduce strategies to generate synthetic labels for active party and synthetic features for passive party respectively. The proposed strategies are designed to prevent the malicious parties from distinguishing which data point is synthetic while maintaining the model performance.

Synthetic Labels Generation for Passive Party.

The gradient g𝑔g sent to the passive party is a matrix in ℝB×dsuperscriptℝ𝐵𝑑\mathbb{R}^{B\times d} with each row belonging to a specific sample ID in the batch with size B𝐵B. Here the gradients as rows of the matrix are gradients of the loss with respect to intermediate computation results of different samples. Synthetic gradients should be provided for samples which are not in the sample ID space (ℐasubscriptℐ𝑎\mathcal{I}_{a}) of the active party to protect privacy. There are two ways to generate synthetic gradients: 1) generate synthetic labels firstly and use the corresponding labels to compute training loss and then generate the corresponding gradients; 2) generate synthetic gradients directly without setting labels. We design several strategies such as k-nearest neighbors to generate synthetic gradients from actual gradients and empirically find these strategies insecure, i.e., the passive party can distinguish synthetic gradients from real ones. Therefore we focus on generating synthetic labels.

The synthetic label generation strategy is based on the following observation: the datasets in many real-world applications such as online advertising and healthcare are imbalanced. The negative samples significantly outnumber the positive ones. For example, Criteo222https://www.kaggle.com/c/criteo-display-ad-challenge/data and Avazu333https://www.kaggle.com/c/avazu-ctr-prediction/data are two real-world large-scale binary classification datasets, and both datasets are highly imbalanced: only 25%percent2525\% of the Criteo and 17%percent1717\% of the Avazu samples are positive. Hence, given a binary classification problem, it’s reasonable to assign the missing labels as negative (00 as the label).

Synthetic Features Generation for Active Party.

For sample IDs not in ℐpsubscriptℐ𝑝\mathcal{I}_{p}, the passive party generates synthetic raw features for them. A naive strategy is to generate random values as synthetic features. However, random values and real features have different distributions; the active party can utilize tools like clustering and outlier detection from robust statistics to decide which features are synthetic and then ℐpsubscriptℐ𝑝\mathcal{I}_{p} is leaked to the active party. Empirically we demonstrated the effectiveness of using SVD-based outlier detection method Tran et al. (2018) to distinguish random values from real features.

We present our method that best protects the privacy. We show that, theoretically, the best strategy for the 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} is to generate synthetic features according to the marginal distribution of real data. Let D​(x,y)𝐷𝑥𝑦D(x,y) be the (unknown) ground truth distribution of the feature-label pairs whose IDs are not owned by 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p}, and q​(⋅)𝑞⋅q(\cdot) be the distribution of labels of those data. As 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} does not have access to labels, its generation strategy can be characterized by a distribution p​(⋅)𝑝⋅p(\cdot). That is, whenever the passive party needs to generate a synthetic feature, it samples from p𝑝p. Because features and labels are independent for synthetic data, the joint distribution is of the form D′​(x,y)=p​(x)⋅q​(y)superscript𝐷′𝑥𝑦⋅𝑝𝑥𝑞𝑦D^{\prime}(x,y)=p(x)\cdot q(y). In order to have the best privacy, we want D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime} to be as close as possible. The following theorem suggests that the marginal distribution is optimal in minimizing KL-divergence. The proof is included in Appendix B.

Theorem 2 (folklore).

Let p𝑝p be a distribution over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and q𝑞q be a distribution over 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}. Let D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} be a joint distribution over 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y} given by D′​(x,y)=p​(x)​q​(y)superscript𝐷′𝑥𝑦𝑝𝑥𝑞𝑦D^{\prime}(x,y)=p(x)q(y). Let p∗superscript𝑝p^{*} be a distribution over 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} given by p∗​(x)=∫yD​(x,y)​𝑑ysuperscript𝑝𝑥subscript𝑦𝐷𝑥𝑦differential-d𝑦p^{*}(x)=\int_{y}D(x,y)dy. Then KL(D||D′)\text{KL}(D||D^{\prime}) is minimized when p=p∗𝑝superscript𝑝p=p^{*}.

Nevertheless, 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} has no access to p∗superscript𝑝p^{*} because 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} simply does not have these features. Here we make the assumption that the data distribution is the same across data corresponding to ID sets ℐa∩ℐpsubscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝\mathcal{I}_{a}\cap\mathcal{I}_{p}, ℐa−ℐpsubscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝\mathcal{I}_{a}-\mathcal{I}_{p} and ℐp−ℐasubscriptℐ𝑝subscriptℐ𝑎\mathcal{I}_{p}-\mathcal{I}_{a}. Then 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} could think of its feature set 𝒳psubscript𝒳𝑝\mathcal{X}_{p} follows the distribution of p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}.

As it is difficult to accurately estimate marginal distribution on input features (a high dimension distribution), we use the following sampling method to generate synthetic features: the passive party uses a random real sample to fill in the non-existing features. The raw features (including real and synthetic) will be fed to the same network and generate the intermediate embeddings at the cut layer.

Logits Calibration.

As our data generation scheme changes the data distribution, it can cause large adaptive calibration (ACE) error (Nixon et al., 2019). ACE measures how well a model’s predicted probabilities of outcomes reflect true probabilities of those outcomes. We adapt a method named logits shift (Chapelle et al., 2015) to handle the calibration error. On a high level, since both parties know how synthetic data is generated, they can estimate how the data distribution deviates from the underlying one, which allows them to modify the model to account for ACE. Empirically we demonstrated that this method can reduce the ACE significantly. Details of how to do the calibration via logits shift can be seen in the appendix.

3 Empirical Study

In this section, we experimentally evaluate the proposed framework. Since PSU is an alignment protocol and it is proved to be secure, the main goal of the empirical study is to demonstrate the effectiveness of the data generation strategies. We run three groups of simulations: 1) Simulations with Synthetic Labels Only. During training, partial labels of the active party are synthetic. We measure the performance of our proposed synthetic label generation with varying synthetic label ratio β𝛽\beta. 2) Simulations with Synthetic Features Only. During training, partial features provided by the passive party are synthetic. We check the performance with varying synthetic feature ratio α𝛼\alpha. 3) Simulations with Both Synthetic Labels and Features. During training, partial data of both parties are synthetic. We check our performance with varying α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta.

Dataset and Model.

We use two real-world datasets: Criteo and Avazu. Criteo is a large-scale binary classification dataset with approximately 454545 million user click records in online advertising. Avazu contains approximately 404040 million entries (111111 days of clicks/not clicks of Avazu data). We defer the similar results on Avazu to Appendix I and only report the results of Criteo in this section. We split each dataset randomly into two parts: with 90%percent9090\% for training and the rest for tests. We train a modified Wide&Deep model (Cheng et al., 2016) where the passive party consists of embedding layers for input features and two layers of 128128128-unit ReLU activated multilayer perceptron (half deep part) and the active party consists of the last two layers of the deep part. In every iteration, the passive party sends a mini-batch of 8,19281928,192 examples’ 128128128-dimensional vectors to the active party and the active party sends the gradients of the loss w.r.t. these vectors back to the passive side.

Evaluation Metrics.

We measure the model utility by the AUC and ACE. A model with an ideal utility should have a high AUC and a low ACE. We also measure the security of the synthetic data generation stage since an honest-but-curious party could try to infer which data samples from the other party are synthetic or real. Therefore it might introduce new membership leakage. To this end, theoretically we can estimate the difference between the distribution D𝐷D of actual data and the distribution D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} of synthetic data. Yet these distributions are over high-dimensional data and it is intractable to compute the distance. Instead, we use spectral attack (Tran et al., 2018), a 2-clustering outlier detection algorithm that can be used to predict if an embedding or gradient is real or synthetic. The AUC of its prediction, which we call it as attack AUC, measures how well the malicious parties could distinguish real data and synthetic data generated by our strategies. A closer to 0.50.50.5 attack AUC is considered to be more secure. More details on the spectral attack can be found in Appendix C.

3.1 Simulations with Synthetic Labels Only

We conduct experiments to simulate the scenario that only the active party has to provide synthetic labels for unowned instances during training. The passive party owns all the sample IDs and hence it provides real features for all training instances. Based on the observation that both Criteo and Avazu datasets are highly imbalanced (only 25%percent2525\% of the samples in Criteo and 17%percent1717\% in Avazu are positive), our label-majority generates synthetic label yi~=0~subscript𝑦𝑖0\widetilde{y_{i}}=0, ∀i​di∉ℐafor-all𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖subscriptℐ𝑎\forall\ {id}_{i}\notin\mathcal{I}_{a}. We also test several other synthetic label generation strategies for the active party: ∀i​di∉ℐafor-all𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖subscriptℐ𝑎\forall\ {id}_{i}\notin\mathcal{I}_{a}, 1) label-minority sets yi~=1~subscript𝑦𝑖1\widetilde{y_{i}}=1; 2) label-random-pos randomly samples a label for yi~~subscript𝑦𝑖\widetilde{y_{i}}, based on the positive instance ratio of 𝒟asubscript𝒟𝑎\mathcal{D}_{a}; 3) label-random-pred randomly samples a label for yi~~subscript𝑦𝑖\widetilde{y_{i}}, based on the predicted positive probability for i​di𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖{id}_{i}; 4) label-neighbors determines yi~~subscript𝑦𝑖\widetilde{y_{i}}, based on a k-nearest-neighbors strategy (with k=3𝑘3k=3 and cosine similarity to measure the similarity between cut layer embeddings).

We test different synthetic label ratio β𝛽\beta and report performance from different generation strategies. We compare the above generation strategies with two baselines. 1) baseline-partial: Given a β𝛽\beta, it only uses the rest (1−β)1𝛽(1-\beta) real labels to train the model; 2) baseline-full: it uses the whole real dataset to train the model, which can be viewed as an upper-bound for all competitors.

For each β𝛽\beta, every experiment uses the same fixed random seed to select unowned instances of the passive party. All strategies have the same real data as used in baseline-partial to train the model. The corresponding results of AUC and ACE are shown in Figure  2 (a) and (d) respectively. We can observe that using less data decreases the model performance. Unsurprisingly, the gap between baseline-partial and baseline-full gradually enlarges with increasing β𝛽\beta. For example, when β=95%𝛽percent95\beta=95\%, baseline-partial drops about 3.8%percent3.83.8\% in comparing with baseline-full.

As shown in Figure 2 (a), label-majority can achieve comparable AUC with baseline-partial. However, label-majority changes the data distribution and causes high ACE. As shown in Figure 2 (d), label-majority has a larger ACE than baselines, and therefore it is necessary to calibrate the predicted logits for label-majority. Depending on when to have the calibration, we provide two variants of label-majority: label-majority-te and label-majority-tr. For label-majority-te, we leave the training logits unchanged and perform the calibration in the testing. For label-majority-tr, we only calibrates the predicted logits in the training. More details are included in Appendix E.

As shown in Figure 2 (d), we find both options reduce the ACE significantly and achieve similar ACE with baselines. Regarding the AUC, label-majority-tr only drops about 0.67%percent0.670.67\% and 0.33%percent0.330.33\% in comparing with baseline-partial when β𝛽\beta is 95%percent9595\% and 50%percent5050\% respectively. Meanwhile, as shown in Table 1, the attack AUC of label-majority and its variants are all around 0.570.570.57. Though label-random-pred has the best privacy among all competitors (detailed analysis can be seen in Appendix H), its utility is worse than label-majority. Therefore our proposed label-majority is highly effective in both protecting privacy and maintaining model utility.

3.2 Simulations with Synthetic Features Only

We conduct experiments to simulate the scenario that only the passive party has to generate synthetic features for unknown instances during training. The active party owns all the sample IDs and it uses real labels for all training instances. We provide other two strategies for the passive party to generate synthetic cut layer embeddings instead of raw features as comparison partners. 1) fea-Gaussian: Inside a mini-batch, each synthetic cut layer embedding f​(x)~~𝑓𝑥\widetilde{f(x)} is generated from 𝒩​(0,(s/d)⋅maxi∈IpB⁡‖f​(xi)‖22​Id×d)𝒩0⋅𝑠𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝐼𝑝𝐵superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖22subscript𝐼𝑑𝑑\mathcal{N}(0,{(s/d)\cdot\max_{i\in I_{p}}^{B}\left\|f(x_{i})\right\|_{2}^{2}}I_{d\times d}), where B𝐵B is the mini-bath size and s𝑠s is tuned as 111. 2) fea-random: Each f​(x)~~𝑓𝑥\widetilde{f(x)} is generated from 𝒩​(μ,σ2)𝒩𝜇superscript𝜎2\mathcal{N}(\mu,\sigma^{2}), where μ𝜇\mu and σ𝜎\sigma are the current moving average of real cut layer embeddings’ mean and standard deviation respectively. Following the similar setting as described in in Section 3.1, we also provide two baselines: baseline-partial and baseline-full and two variant of fea-sampling with logits calibration: fea-sampling-te and fea-sampling-tr. Details of the logits calibration can be found in Appendix F.

We vary the synthetic feature ratio α𝛼\alpha to in our experiments. As shown in Figure 2 (b) and (e), fea-Gaussian and fea-random have comparable AUC with baseline-partial. However, both of them have no privacy guarantee, since their attack AUC are close to 1.01.01.0 as shown in Table 2. In addition, fea-sampling-te and fea-sampling-tr reduce the ACE significantly and have comparable ACE with baseline-partial. Regarding AUC, fea-sampling-tr drops about 4.9%percent4.94.9\% and 0.77%percent0.770.77\% in comparing with baseline-partial when α=0.95𝛼0.95\alpha=0.95 and α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5 respectively. Meanwhile, the attack AUC of fea-sampling and its variants all fall in [0.5,0.507]0.50.507[0.5,0.507] (almost 0.50.50.5), as shown in Table 2.

3.3 Simulations with Both Synthetic Labels and Features

We conduct experiments with a more realistic scenario: both parties provide synthetic data. We vary β𝛽\beta in the passive party and α𝛼\alpha in the active party and compare our proposed approach FLORIST-vanilla and FLORIST with baselines (baseline-full and baseline-partial). Both FLORIST-vanilla and FLORIST leverage label-majority to generate synthetic labels and fea-sampling to generate synthetic features. The difference is that FLORIST leverages logits calibration to reduce ACE caused by synthetic features and labels, while FLORIST-vanilla only deals with calibration with label-majority-te. Both parties may add dummy sample IDs to perturb the union of training samples. Hence, training instances with synthetic label and feature simultaneously are allowed in our experiments.

Due to space limit, we only report our experimental results with α=β𝛼𝛽\alpha=\beta. We find the same conclusion under other settings. The real data ratio used to train the model is (1−α)​(1−β)1𝛼1𝛽(1-\alpha)(1-\beta). For example, when the synthetic ratio per party is 0.950.950.95, baseline-partial leverages 0.25%percent0.250.25\% data to train. As shown in Figure 2 (c) and (f), FLORIST and FLORIST-vanilla achieve similar AUC. However, FLORIST can reduce the ACE significantly in comparing with baseline-partial. As shown in Table  3, FLORIST has a reasonable AUC drop in comparing with baseline-partial.

Figure 2 (h), (i), and (j) shows the convergence analysis for FLORIST with different α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta. 4 Related Work

Vertical Federated Learning.

Vertical Federated Learning (Vepakomma et al., 2018; Gupta and Raskar, 2018; Abuadbba et al., 2020; Ceballos et al., 2020) considers the scenario where multiple parties own different attributes of the same entities. Existing vFL protocols (Yang et al., 2019b; Chen et al., 2020; Wu et al., 2020) are all based on identifying and then training the model on the intersection. Therefore it would unavoidably leak the intersection membership. Our work is also closely related to Split Neural Network (SplitNN) (Vepakomma et al., 2018; Gupta and Raskar, 2018; Abuadbba et al., 2020; Ceballos et al., 2020), which is another framework that can be used in vFL scenario.

Private Set Union.

Despite extensive study on PSI (De Cristofaro and Tsudik, 2010; De Cristofaro et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2012; Hazay and Venkitasubramaniam, 2017; Pinkas et al., 2019), little is known on PSU until the work of Kissner and Song (Kissner and Song, 2005). Existing work on PSU employs advanced techniques in multi-party computation including additive homomorphic encryption (Kissner and Song, 2005; Frikken, 2007; Davidson and Cid, 2017), Bloom filter (Davidson and Cid, 2017), garbling circuits (Blanton and Aguiar, 2016), and oblivious transfer (Blanton and Aguiar, 2016; Kolesnikov et al., 2019). Different from prior work, we compute the union of hash function of the ID sets so that the raw ID information is not used in the training procedure. Our PSU protocol is based on the Diffie–Hellman key exchange scheme (Diffie and Hellman, 1976), and is inspired by the work of Buddhavarapu et.al. (Buddhavarapu et al., 2020). Compared to (Buddhavarapu et al., 2020), our protocol is conceptually cleaner because we decouple the union computation from identifying the hash mapping.

5 Conclusion

We propose a novel vFL framework that addresses the intersection membership leakage problem which currently prevents many privacy-sensitive organizations from adopting vFL. Our framework uses PSU to generate a union of all samples, which does not reveal intersection membership information to all parties. In addition, synthetic data generation strategies are proposed to handle samples belong to the union but not the intersection. We experimentally show that our method can protect the intersection membership without a significant drop in model performance.

Limitations.

We point out two limitations in our framework. First, compared to the PSI approach, our PSU increases the training sample size from the intersection size (|ℐp∩ℐa|subscriptℐ𝑝subscriptℐ𝑎|\mathcal{I}_{p}\cap\mathcal{I}_{a}|) to the union size (|ℐp∪ℐa|subscriptℐ𝑝subscriptℐ𝑎|\mathcal{I}_{p}\cup\mathcal{I}_{a}|). Therefore, when the union is significantly larger than the intersection, our method would incur a non-negligible training cost compared to PSI. In practice, the larger party can choose to downsample its data to reduce training overhead. In addition, before the training starts, parties can estimate the additional training cost by measuring the size difference between intersection and union, and then choose between our framework and traditional PSI. Second, synthetic label generation label-majority is specifically designed for unbalanced binary classification tasks such as online advertising and healthcare applications. We leave a more general strategy (other than label-random-pred) for balanced binary classification and multi-classification problems as future work.

Appendix A Security Analysis of Private Set Union

We first introduce some notations in multi-party computation adapted from Lindell [2017]. The view of a party P𝑃P (either 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} or 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p}), consists of the input of P𝑃P (either ℐasubscriptℐ𝑎\mathcal{I}_{a} or ℐpsubscriptℐ𝑝\mathcal{I}_{p}), the internal randomness used by P𝑃P, and all the messages P𝑃P receives during the MPC procedure. Let n=max⁡{|ℐa|,|ℐp|,⌈log⁡p⌉}𝑛subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝𝑝n=\max\{|\mathcal{I}_{a}|,|\mathcal{I}_{p}|,\lceil\log p\rceil\} be the security parameter, where p𝑝p is the prime number used in Algorithm 1. A simulator S𝑆S for P𝑃P is a probabilistic algorithm that takes the input of P𝑃P and |ℐa|,|ℐp|,|ℐa∪ℐp|subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝|\mathcal{I}_{a}|,|\mathcal{I}_{p}|,|\mathcal{I}_{a}\cup\mathcal{I}_{p}| as input, runs in time polynomial in n𝑛n, and outputs a transcript that is indistinguishable to the view of P𝑃P for any polynomial time algorithm.

The idea behind simulation based proof is that for honest-but-curious malicious party, all the information it could inspect is from its view. Therefore, if the view of malicious party is indistinguishable to the output of the simulator, then any polynomial time malicious party cannot infer more information other than the input of the simulator.

Now we can state our formal result on the security of our PSU protocol. We first present a simulator Sasubscript𝑆𝑎S_{a} against 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a}, which is described in Algorithm 2. The security guarantee is shown in Theorem 3

Theorem 3.

Assume that the Decisional Diffie–Hellman problem is hard for Q​R​(ℤp∗)𝑄𝑅superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑝QR(\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{*}). Then the distribution of the view of 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} by running Algorithm 1 is indistinguishable to the output of Sasubscript𝑆𝑎S_{a} for any distinguisher that runs in time polynomial in n𝑛n.

Proof.

The proof follows from Buddhavarapu et al. [2020] and adapts a hybrid argument. Notice that the output of Sasubscript𝑆𝑎S_{a} is essentially replacing the messages from 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} with proper random elements from ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q}. Therefore we can build a sequence of hybrid views, where we start with the view of 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} by really executing Algorithm 1, and we end with the view that is the output of Sasubscript𝑆𝑎S_{a}. Furthermore, neighboring hybrid views only differ at one place. We are going to argue that distinguishing neighboring views can be reduced to the DDH problem, hence proves the security.

Let us see a concrete example. Assume that for two neighboring views visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}, vi+1subscript𝑣𝑖1v_{i+1}, the only difference is that in Line (2), for one single x∈ℐa−ℐp𝑥subscriptℐ𝑎subscriptℐ𝑝x\in\mathcal{I}_{a}-\mathcal{I}_{p}, visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} uses xs1​t1superscript𝑥subscript𝑠1subscript𝑡1x^{s_{1}t_{1}}, while vi+1subscript𝑣𝑖1v_{i+1} uses gs1superscript𝑔subscript𝑠1g^{s_{1}} for some g∈G𝑔𝐺g\in G. We now construct a reduction from DDH to distinguish these two views. Recall that in DDH, we are given a tuple (ha,hb,hc)superscriptℎ𝑎superscriptℎ𝑏superscriptℎ𝑐(h^{a},h^{b},h^{c}) where hℎh is a generator of Q​R​(ℤp∗)𝑄𝑅superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑝QR(\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{*}), and we need to decide if c=a​b𝑐𝑎𝑏c=ab, or c𝑐c is a random number from ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q}. Then we construct an instance of PSU as follows: we set xs1=hbsuperscript𝑥subscript𝑠1superscriptℎ𝑏x^{s_{1}}=h^{b} and t1=asubscript𝑡1𝑎t_{1}=a. Then in visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}, the tuple (ht1,xs1,xs1​t1)superscriptℎsubscript𝑡1superscript𝑥subscript𝑠1superscript𝑥subscript𝑠1subscript𝑡1(h^{t_{1}},x^{s_{1}},x^{s_{1}t_{1}}) is distributed as (ha,hb,ha​b)superscriptℎ𝑎superscriptℎ𝑏superscriptℎ𝑎𝑏(h^{a},h^{b},h^{ab}), while in v2subscript𝑣2v_{2}, (ht1,xs1,xs1​t1¯)superscriptℎsubscript𝑡1superscript𝑥subscript𝑠1¯superscript𝑥subscript𝑠1subscript𝑡1(h^{t_{1}},x^{s_{1}},\overline{x^{s_{1}t_{1}}}) is distributed as (ha,hb,gs1)superscriptℎ𝑎superscriptℎ𝑏superscript𝑔subscript𝑠1(h^{a},h^{b},g^{s_{1}}). Since g𝑔g is uniform random, gs1superscript𝑔subscript𝑠1g^{s_{1}} is distributed as hcsuperscriptℎ𝑐h^{c} for random c∈ℤq𝑐subscriptℤ𝑞c\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}. Hence if some distinguisher can distinguish visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} and vi+1subscript𝑣𝑖1v_{i+1}, then it can be used to solve DDH. ∎

We next present a simulator Spsubscript𝑆𝑝S_{p} against 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} in Algorithm 3. Since Algorithm 1 is highly symmetric, the corresponding security proof is quite similar and is hence omitted. The security guarantee is summarized in the following theorem:

Theorem 4.

Assume that the Decisional Diffie–Hellman problem is hard for Q​R​(ℤp∗)𝑄𝑅superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑝QR(\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{*}). Then the distribution of the view of 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} by running Algorithm 1 is indistinguishable to the output of Spsubscript𝑆𝑝S_{p} for any distinguisher that runs in time polynomial in n𝑛n.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 2

In this section we present the proof of Theorem 2.

Proof.

From the definition of KL-divergence, we have

Appendix C Spectral Attack

In this section we present the theoretical background of the spectral attack. Spectral attack is a singular value decomposition (SVD) based outlier detection method introduced by Tran, Li and Madry Tran et al. [2018]. In particular, they show that

Lemma 1 (Lemma 3.1, Definition 3.1 in Tran et al. [2018]).

Fix 0<ϵ<120italic-ϵ120<\epsilon<\frac{1}{2}. Let D𝐷D, W𝑊W be two distributions over ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} with mean μD,μWsubscript𝜇𝐷subscript𝜇𝑊\mu_{D},\mu_{W} and covariance matrices ΣD,ΣWsubscriptΣ𝐷subscriptΣ𝑊\Sigma_{D},\Sigma_{W}. Let F𝐹F be a mixture distribution given by F=(1−ϵ)​D+ϵ​W𝐹1italic-ϵ𝐷italic-ϵ𝑊F=(1-\epsilon)D+\epsilon W. If ‖μD−μW‖22≥6​σ2ϵsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝜇𝐷subscript𝜇𝑊226superscript𝜎2italic-ϵ\|\mu_{D}-\mu_{W}\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{6\sigma^{2}}{\epsilon}, then the following statement holds: let μFsubscript𝜇𝐹\mu_{F} be the mean of F𝐹F and v𝑣v be the top singular vector of the covariance matrix of F𝐹F, then there exists t𝑡t>0 so that

PrX∼D⁡[|⟨X−μF,v⟩|>t]<subscriptPrsimilar-to𝑋𝐷𝑋subscript𝜇𝐹𝑣𝑡absent\displaystyle\Pr_{X\sim D}[|\langle X-\mu_{F},v\rangle|>t]< ϵ,italic-ϵ\displaystyle~{}\epsilon,
PrX∼W⁡[|⟨X−μF,v⟩|<t]<subscriptPrsimilar-to𝑋𝑊𝑋subscript𝜇𝐹𝑣𝑡absent\displaystyle\Pr_{X\sim W}[|\langle X-\mu_{F},v\rangle|<t]< ϵ.italic-ϵ\displaystyle~{}\epsilon.

This gives us one attack method to distinguish the distribution D𝐷D of real data between the distribution D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} of synthetic data. Lemma 1 suggests that if the mean of D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} are far away from each other, then we can use |⟨X−μF,v⟩|𝑋subscript𝜇𝐹𝑣|\langle X-\mu_{F},v\rangle| as the indicator to distinguish D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}.

In experiments, for each mini-batch, we compute the attack AUC for the passive party 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} when the synthetic label ratio β>0𝛽0\beta>0 and for the active party 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} when the synthetic feature ratio α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. For 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p}, we consider the distribution over the gradients g𝑔g sent back by 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a}. For 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a}, we consider the joint distribution over the intermediate embeddings f𝑓f sent from 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} and the labels y𝑦y. We estimate μFsubscript𝜇𝐹\mu_{F} and v𝑣v by computing the empirical mean and covariance matrix with data in the mini-batch. Then we are able to compute the score |⟨X−μF,v⟩|𝑋subscript𝜇𝐹𝑣|\langle X-\mu_{F},v\rangle| for each sample in the batch. Finally, we compute the attack AUC as how these scores predict if each sample is synthetic or not.

Appendix D Federated Model Training and Serving

After we leverage PSU to align the dataset and provide synthetic data using strategies as described in previous subsection, we then introduce how to do the federated model training and serving. In this paper we focus on two parties learning a model for a binary classification problem over the domain 𝒳×{0,1}𝒳01\mathcal{X}\times\left\{0,1\right\}. Here the passive and active parties want to learn a composition model h∘fℎ𝑓h\circ f jointly, where the raw features X𝑋X and f:𝒳→ℝd:𝑓→𝒳superscriptℝ𝑑f:\mathcal{X}\to\operatorname{\mathbb{R}}^{d} are stored on the passive party side while the labels y𝑦y and h:ℝd→ℝ:ℎ→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝh:\operatorname{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\to\operatorname{\mathbb{R}} is on the active party side. Let ℓ=h​(f​(X))ℓℎ𝑓𝑋\ell=h(f(X)) be the logit of the positive class where the positive class’s predicted probability is given by the sigmoid function. The loss of the model is given by the cross entropy.

To train the model using gradient descent, the passive party computes f​(X)𝑓𝑋f(X) with both synthetic and real raw features X𝑋X and sends it to the active party who will then complete the rest of computation (Forward in Table 4).555 For the simplifying of the notation and derivation, we add no additional features in the active party to compute the logit. The data generation strategies can be adapted for other complicated settings. Then the active party starts the gradient computation process by first computing the gradient of the loss with respect to the logit d​Ld​ℓ=(p¯1−y)𝑑𝐿𝑑ℓsubscript¯𝑝1𝑦\frac{dL}{d\ell}=(\overline{p}_{1}-y). Here y𝑦y contains both synthetic and real labels. Using the chain rule, the active party can then compute the gradient of L𝐿L with respect to hℎh’s parameters through ℓℓ\ell. In order to allow the passive party to learn f𝑓f, the active party also computes the gradient of L𝐿L with respect to the input of the function hℎh. We denote this gradient by g𝑔g (equality by chain rule). After receiving g𝑔g sent from the active party, the passive party can compute the gradient of L𝐿L w.r.t. f𝑓f’s parameters (Backward in Table 4).

When B𝐵B examples are forwarded as a batch, the communicated features f​(X)𝑓𝑋f(X) and gradients g𝑔g will both be matrices of shape ℝB×dsuperscriptℝ𝐵𝑑\operatorname{\mathbb{R}}^{B\times d} with each row belonging to a specific example in the batch. It is important to note that here the gradients as rows of the matrix are gradients of the loss with respect to different examples’ intermediate computation results but not the model parameters; therefore, no averaging over or shuffling of the rows of the matrix can be done prior to communication for the sake of correct gradient computation of f𝑓f’s parameters on the passive party side.

For model inference, suppose that the passive party would like to know the prediction of instance i𝑖i from the active party. The passive party only feeds i𝑖i’s raw feature x𝑥x and computes f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x). If no additional features are added in the active party to compute the logit, then the active party directly computes pi=1/(1+exp⁡(−h​(f​(x))))subscript𝑝𝑖11ℎ𝑓𝑥p_{i}=1/(1+\exp(-h(f(x)))) and sends pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} to the passive party without knowing any ID information of i𝑖i. Otherwise if additional features are needed for active party, the passive party can hide instance i𝑖i in a batch which both parties have agreements on. Then the serving process will be the as same as the forward process during the training phase. After receiving a batch of predictions from the active party, the passive party can select the corresponding prediction for i𝑖i.

Appendix E Logits Calibration for Synthetic Labels Only

Here we present the logits shift method inspired by Chapelle et al. [2015]. In this section we consider the scenario where only the active party needs to provide synthetic labels, and the synthetic labels are generated by label-majority. Let D𝐷D be the ground truth distribution over 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}. Let D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} be the distribution of data after introducing synthetic data. Let δi​da=𝟏i​d∈ℐasubscriptsuperscript𝛿𝑎𝑖𝑑subscript1𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑎\delta^{a}_{id}=\mathbf{1}_{id\in\mathcal{I}_{a}}, and pasubscript𝑝𝑎p_{a} be the probability of i​d∈ℐa𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑎id\in\mathcal{I}_{a}. We make the assumption that the underlying ground-truth label distribution is independent on whether i​d∈ℐa𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑎id\in\mathcal{I}_{a}. Then we have

D′​(y=1|X=x)superscript𝐷′𝑦conditional1𝑋𝑥\displaystyle~{}D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x) (1)
=\displaystyle= ∑δi​da=01Pr[δi​da]D′(y=1|X=x,δi​da)\displaystyle~{}\sum_{\delta^{a}_{id}=0}^{1}\Pr[\delta^{a}_{id}]D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x,\delta^{a}_{id})
=\displaystyle= Pr[δi​da=1]D′(y=1|X=x,δi​da=1)+Pr[δi​da=0]D′(y=1|X=x,δi​da=0)\displaystyle~{}\Pr[\delta^{a}_{id}=1]D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x,\delta^{a}_{id}=1)+\Pr[\delta^{a}_{id}=0]D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x,\delta^{a}_{id}=0)
=\displaystyle= pa​D​(y=1|X=x).subscript𝑝𝑎𝐷𝑦conditional1𝑋𝑥\displaystyle~{}p_{a}D(y=1|X=x).

There are two ways to interpret Eq. (1):

  • •

    label-majority-te: We think of D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} as the model output, and do not modify the training phase. We compute D𝐷D according to Eq. (1) to evaluate on the test dataset.

  • •

    label-majority-tr: We think of D𝐷D as the model output, and use it to evaluate in the test phase. In the training phase, we compute D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} according to Eq. (1) to compute the loss and corresponding model updates.

Empirically we found both logits shift can reduce the ACE significantly in comparing with the vanilla label-majority without any logits shift.

Appendix F Logits Calibration for Synthetic Features Only

In this section we consider the scenario where only the passive party needs to provide synthetic features, and the synthetic features are generated by fea-sampling. Let D𝐷D be the ground truth distribution over 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}. Let D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} be the distribution of data after introducing synthetic data. We make the assumption that the underlying ground-truth label distribution is independent on whether i​d∈ℐp𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑝id\in\mathcal{I}_{p}. Then we have

D′​(y=1|X=x)superscript𝐷′𝑦conditional1𝑋𝑥\displaystyle~{}D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x) (2)
=\displaystyle= ∑δi​dp=01Pr[δi​dp]D′(y=1|X=x,δi​dp)\displaystyle~{}\sum_{\delta^{p}_{id}=0}^{1}\Pr[\delta^{p}_{id}]D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x,\delta^{p}_{id})
=\displaystyle= Pr[δi​dp=1]D′(y=1|X=x,δi​dp=1)+Pr[δi​dp=0]D′(y=1|X=x,δi​dp=0)\displaystyle~{}\Pr[\delta^{p}_{id}=1]D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x,\delta^{p}_{id}=1)+\Pr[\delta^{p}_{id}=0]D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x,\delta^{p}_{id}=0)
=\displaystyle= pp​D​(y=1|X=x)+(1−pp)​D​(y=1).subscript𝑝𝑝𝐷𝑦conditional1𝑋𝑥1subscript𝑝𝑝𝐷𝑦1\displaystyle~{}p_{p}D(y=1|X=x)+(1-p_{p})D(y=1).

In the experiment, ppsubscript𝑝𝑝p_{p} is known by both parties, and D​(y=1)𝐷𝑦1D(y=1) is estimated by the marginal distribution of true labels owned by 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a}. Similarly, there are two ways to interpret Eq. (2):

  • •

    fea-sampling-te: We think of D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} as the model output, and do not modify the training phase. We compute D𝐷D according to Eq. (2) to evaluate on the test dataset.

  • •

    fea-sampling-tr: We think of D𝐷D as the model output, and use it to evaluate in the test phase. In the training phase, we compute D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} according to Eq. (2) to compute the loss and corresponding model updates.

Appendix G Logits Calibration for Synthetic Both Features and Labels

Here we present a toy example of our logits shift method. Consider ℐasubscriptℐ𝑎\mathcal{I}_{a} and ℐpsubscriptℐ𝑝\mathcal{I}_{p} are constructed as follows: we start from a superset ℐℐ\mathcal{I}, and for each i​d∈ℐ𝑖𝑑ℐid\in\mathcal{I}, with probability pasubscript𝑝𝑎p_{a} we place i​d𝑖𝑑id into ℐasubscriptℐ𝑎\mathcal{I}_{a}, and with probability ppsubscript𝑝𝑝p_{p} we place i​d𝑖𝑑id into ℐpsubscriptℐ𝑝\mathcal{I}_{p} independently. Finally we run over vFL protocol by using ℐℐ\mathcal{I} for scheduling. 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} uses fill-major strategy to generate synthetic labels, and 𝒫psubscript𝒫𝑝\mathcal{P}_{p} uses raw-sampling strategy to generate synthetic features.

Let D𝐷D be the ground truth distribution over 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}. Let D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} be the distribution of data after introducing synthetic data. Let δi​da=𝟏i​d∈ℐasubscriptsuperscript𝛿𝑎𝑖𝑑subscript1𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑎\delta^{a}_{id}=\mathbf{1}_{id\in\mathcal{I}_{a}} and δi​dp=𝟏i​d∈ℐpsubscriptsuperscript𝛿𝑝𝑖𝑑subscript1𝑖𝑑subscriptℐ𝑝\delta^{p}_{id}=\mathbf{1}_{id\in\mathcal{I}_{p}}. Then we have

D′​(y=1|X=x)=superscript𝐷′𝑦conditional1𝑋𝑥absent\displaystyle D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x)= ∑δi​da=01∑δi​dp=01Pr[δi​da,δi​dp]D′(y=1|X=x,δi​da,δi​dp)\displaystyle~{}\sum_{\delta^{a}_{id}=0}^{1}\sum_{\delta^{p}_{id}=0}^{1}\Pr[\delta^{a}_{id},\delta^{p}_{id}]D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x,\delta^{a}_{id},\delta^{p}_{id}) (3)
=\displaystyle= Pr[δi​da=1,δi​dp=1]D′(y=1|X=x,δi​da=1,δi​dp=1)\displaystyle~{}\Pr[\delta^{a}_{id}=1,\delta^{p}_{id}=1]D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x,\delta^{a}_{id}=1,\delta^{p}_{id}=1)
+Pr[δi​da=1,δi​dp=0]D′(y=1|X=x,δi​da=0,δi​dp=0)\displaystyle+\Pr[\delta^{a}_{id}=1,\delta^{p}_{id}=0]D^{\prime}(y=1|X=x,\delta^{a}_{id}=0,\delta^{p}_{id}=0)
=\displaystyle= pa​pp​D​(y=1|X=x)+pa​(1−pp)​D​(y=1).subscript𝑝𝑎subscript𝑝𝑝𝐷𝑦conditional1𝑋𝑥subscript𝑝𝑎1subscript𝑝𝑝𝐷𝑦1\displaystyle~{}p_{a}p_{p}D(y=1|X=x)+p_{a}(1-p_{p})D(y=1).

There are two ways to apply Eq. (3). We can either think of our model computing D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}, then on test data evaluation, we need to compute D𝐷D from D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}; or we can think of our model computing D𝐷D, then in the training process we need to compute D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} from D𝐷D and use D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} to compute the loss and update the model parameters.

Appendix H Synthetic Label Generation: label-random-pred

In this section we show the theoretical analysis of label-random-pred. It is inspired by the so-called “log-derivative trick”, and the goal is to mitigate the effect of synthetic labels on the model updates. Notice that in binary classification problems, ∀x∈𝒳for-all𝑥𝒳\forall x\in\mathcal{X}, for any prediction model p𝑝p, we always have ∑yi=01p​(yi|x)=1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖01𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑥1\sum_{y_{i}=0}^{1}p(y_{i}|x)=1. Let W𝑊W be the weight on the cut layer, and (x1,y1),(x2,y2),⋯subscript𝑥1subscript𝑦1subscript𝑥2subscript𝑦2⋯(x_{1},y_{1}),(x_{2},y_{2}),\cdots be the training samples in a mini-batch. We can split the indices into two parts I1subscript𝐼1I_{1} and I2subscript𝐼2I_{2}, where I1subscript𝐼1I_{1} are the indices that 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} has the labels, and I2subscript𝐼2I_{2} are the rest indices. Since 𝒫asubscript𝒫𝑎\mathcal{P}_{a} only needs to generate synthetic labels for indices in I2subscript𝐼2I_{2}, we have

∑yi=01qxi​(yi)​∂log⁡p​(yi|xi)∂W=0.superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖01subscript𝑞subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝑊0\displaystyle\sum_{y_{i}=0}^{1}q_{x_{i}}(y_{i})\frac{\partial\log p(y_{i}|x_{i})}{\partial W}=0.

Notice that ∑yi=01qxi​(yi)​log⁡p​(yi|xi)superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖01subscript𝑞subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖\sum_{y_{i}=0}^{1}q_{x_{i}}(y_{i})\log p(y_{i}|x_{i}) can be interpreted as the expectation of the cross-entropy loss if we generate synthetic labels according to qxisubscript𝑞subscript𝑥𝑖q_{x_{i}}. This explains the intuition of label-random-pred: we simply generate the synthetic label yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} according to the model prediction p​(yi|xi)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖p(y_{i}|x_{i}). If q𝑞q and W𝑊W are independent, then the expected gradient with respect to the cross-entropy loss is exactly 00, namely the synthetic labels do not affect model updates on average.

label-random-pred performs better than label-minority, label-neighbors, and label-random-pos. However, the variance could be large when we only sample once to generate the label. To reduce the variance, we can increase the sample times and average the gradients generated from each sampled label. As a result, we can have better performance at the cost of worse privacy, because the gradients corresponding to synthetic labels tend to be close to 0. Such a trade-off can be observed in Table 5. This experiment is conducted on the Avazu dataset with 2 epochs of training.

One advantage of label-random-pred is that it can not only be applied to both balanced and unbalanced binary classification problems but also multi-classification problems.

Appendix I Experimental Results on the Avazu Dataset

In this section, we report the experiment result on Avazu dataset. Avazu is a dataset of click-through data with approximately 40 million entries (11 days of clicks/not clicks of Avazu data). Overall, the trends of all evaluation metrics are very similar to those in the experiments on Cretio reported in Section 3.

I.1 Simulations with Synthetic Labels Only

The experiment results on Avazu dataset of AUC and ACE are shown in Figure 3 (a) and (d) respectively. The attack AUC can be found in Table 6. We can see that label-majority can achieve similar AUC compared to baseline-partial, while maintaining a relatively low attack AUC (about 0.55). Furthermore, by applying logits shift, ACE can be lowered to the scale of baseline-partial. These experiment results reaffirm the validity of using label-majority with logits shift as the generation strategy for the active party.

I.2 Simulations with Synthetic Features Only

The experiment results on Avazu dataset of AUC and ACE are shown in Figure 3 (b) and (e) respectively. The attack AUC can be found in Table 7. Again we find that fea-Gaussian and fea-random have comparable AUC with baseline-partial. However their attack AUC is very close to 111, meaning that they are not suitable for privacy-sensitive vFL. On the other hand, fea-sampling has a reasonable attack AUC, and the drop on AUC is moderate compared to baseline-partial. For instance, the AUC drops about 6.7%percent6.76.7\% and 0.88%percent0.880.88\% compared with baseline-partial when α=0.95𝛼0.95\alpha=0.95 and α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5 respectively. We also observe that logits shift can significantly lower the ACE.

I.3 Simulations with Both Synthetic Labels and Features

As in Section 3, here we report our experimental results with α=β𝛼𝛽\alpha=\beta. The experiment results of AUC and ACE are shown in Figure 3 (c) and (f) respectively. We find that by applying logits shift, FLORIST greatly reduces ACE compared to FLORIST-vanilla. We also report the AUC drop for FLORIST compared to baseline-partial. The drop is barely minimal in scenarios close to real application (like α=β=0.5𝛼𝛽0.5\alpha=\beta=0.5), and is still affordable even when α,β𝛼𝛽\alpha,\beta is as large as 0.950.950.95.

Appendix J Data Setup and Experimental Details

We first describe how we first preprocess each of the datasets. We then describe the model architecture used for each dataset. Finally, we describe what are the training hyperparameters used for each dataset/model combination and the total amount of compute required for the experiments.

Dataset preprocessing

[Criteo]

Every record of Criteo has 272727 categorical input features and 141414 real-valued input features. We first replace all the NA values in categorical features with a single new category (which we represent using the empty string) and all the NA values in real-valued features by 00. For each categorical feature, we convert each of its possible value uniquely to an integer between 00 (inclusive) and the total number of unique categories (exclusive). For each real-valued feature, we linearly normalize it into [0,1]01[0,1]. We then randomly sample 10%percent1010\% of the entire Criteo publicly provided training set as our entire dataset (for faster training to generate privacy-utility trade-off comparision) and further make the subsampled dataset into a 90%-10% train-test split.

[Avazu]

Unlike Criteo, each record in Avazu only has categorical input features. We similarly replace all NA value with a single new category (the empty string), and for each categorical feature, we convert each of its possible value uniquely to an integer between 00 (inclusive) and the total number of unique categories (exclusive). We use all the records in provided in Avazu and randomly split it into 90% for training and 10% for test.

Model architecture details

[Criteo]

We modified a popular deep learning model architecture WDL Cheng et al. [2016] for online advertising. We first process the categorical features in a given record by applying an embedding lookup for every categorical feature’s value. We use an embedding dimension of 4 for the deep part. After the lookup, the deep embeddings are then concatenated with the continuous features to form the raw input vectors for the deep part. The deep part processes the raw features using 4 ReLU-activated 128-unit MLP layers before producing a final logic value. The cut layer is after the output of the 2rd ReLU layer on the deep part.

Model training details

To ensure smooth optimization and sufficient training loss minimization, we use a slightly smaller learning rate than normal.

[Criteo]

We use the Adam optimizer with with a batch size of 8,192 and a learning rate of 1​e1𝑒1e−44-4 throughout the entire training of 3 epochs (approximately 15k stochastic gradient updates).

[Avazu]

We use the Adam optimizer with a batch size of 8,192 and a learning rate of 1​e1𝑒1e−44-4 throughout the entire training of 3 epochs (approximately 15k stochastic gradient updates).

We conduct our experiments over 8 Nvidia Tesla V100 GPU card. Each epoch of run of Avazu takes about 10 hours to finish on a single GPU card occupying 4GB of GPU RAM. Each epoch run of Criteo takes about 11 hours to finish on a single GPU card using 4 GB of GPU RAM.
